result.markdown:
---
title: "Wk 02: Exploring TC journals (pt 1)"
---


## Install packages and read in data

Our source data is split between two CSV files, one for the journal "Technical Communication Quarterly" and one for "Technical Communication."


::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
# install and load packages

#install.packages("tidyverse")
library(tidyverse)
library(readr)

# read in both csv files
tcq_data_raw <- read_csv("data/tcq_wos_data.csv")
tc_data_raw <- read_csv("data/tc_wos_data.csv")
```
:::


## Data preparation 

Let's take a quick look at the data and clean up any issues. Some questions we might answer:

* How many rows and columns are in each dataset?
* What do the rows and columns correspond to?


::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
# shows dimensions (number of rows and columns)
dim(tcq_data_raw) 
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}
```
[1] 582  22
```
:::

```{.r .cell-code}
dim(tc_data_raw)
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}
```
[1] 332  69
```
:::

```{.r .cell-code}
glimpse(tcq_data_raw)
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}

### Cleaning names

We'll start by cleaning up the names with the janitor package. The convention is lowercase and joined by underscores. 


::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
#install.packages("janitor")
library(janitor)

# use help("library_name") for a description
help("janitor") 


# Syntax method 1 (on TCQ)
tcq_data_raw <- clean_names(tcq_data_raw)

glimpse(tcq_data_raw)
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}

:::


### Select columns of interest

Now we'll use a function from a library called dplyr to retain only the columns we want. Let's keep:

* author_full_names
* article_title
* source_title
* abstract
* cited_references
* cited_reference_count
* publication_year
* publication_type

First on TCQ


::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
library(dplyr)

# the select function from dplyr on TCQ data
tcq_clean <- tcq_data_raw %>%
  select(author_full_names,
         article_title,
         source_title,
         abstract,
         cited_references,
         cited_reference_count,
         publication_year,
         publication_type)

glimpse(tcq_clean)
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}
```
Rows: 582
Columns: 8
$ author_full_names     <chr> "Fuglsby, Brandi J.; Veeramoothoo, Saveena (Chak…
$ article_title         <chr> "Regulating Emotions for Social Action: Emotiona…
$ source_title          <chr> "TECHNICAL COMMUNICATION QUARTERLY", "TECHNICAL …
$ abstract              <chr> "This article describes students' emotional inte…
$ cited_references      <chr> "Agboka Godwin Y., 2018, CITIZENSHIP ADVOCACY; […
$ cited_reference_count <dbl> 32, 86, 54, 28, 66, 22, 27, 38, 5, 20, 50, 4, 55…
$ publication_year      <dbl> 2023, 2021, 2020, 2015, 2014, 2013, 2010, 2009, …
$ publication_type      <chr> "J", "J", "J", "J", "J", "J", "J", "J", "J", "J"…
```
:::
:::


Now on TC


::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
# the select function from dplyr on TCQ data
tc_clean <- tc_data_raw %>%
  select(author_full_names,
         article_title,
         source_title,
         abstract,
         cited_references,
         cited_reference_count,
         publication_year,
         publication_type)

glimpse(tc_clean)
```

```
$ cited_reference_count <dbl> 82, 24, 73, 46, 30, 28, 12, 20, 27, 24, 72, 34, …
```

:::


### Combine the two sets


::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
both_data <- rbind(tcq_clean, tc_clean)

dim(both_data)
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}
```
[1] 914   8
```
:::
:::


## Exploring the data

### Some quick ways to examine at a high level


::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
# provides overview of numeric variables
summary(both_data) 
```

```
                    Mean   : 35.59        Mean   :2014                       
                    3rd Qu.: 51.00        3rd Qu.:2019                       
                    Max.   :169.00        Max.   :2023                       
```

### Visualize

Let's create some exploratory visualizations. 

#### Visualize the articles published by year


::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
# count of articles by year
ggplot(both_data, aes(x = publication_year)) +
  geom_bar() +
  labs(title = "Articles per Year in TC and TCQ",
       X = "Publication Year",
       Y = "Number of Articles") +
  theme_light()
```

::: {.cell-output-display}
![](wk02_wos_journals_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-8-1.png){width=672}
:::
:::


#### Add another variable to the display


::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
# count of articles by year, by journal
ggplot(both_data, aes(x = publication_year, fill = source_title)) +
  geom_bar() +
  labs(title = "Articles per Year in TC and TCQ",
       X = "Publication Year",
       Y = "Number of Articles") +
  theme_light()
```

::: {.cell-output-display}
![](wk02_wos_journals_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-9-1.png){width=672}
:::
:::


#### Create two displays using facet wrap


::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
# count of articles by year, by journal
ggplot(both_data, aes(x = publication_year)) +
  geom_bar() +
  labs(title = "Articles per Year in TC and TCQ",
       X = "Publication Year",
       Y = "Number of Articles") +
   facet_wrap(~ source_title, ncol = 2) # Change ncol as needed
```

::: {.cell-output-display}
![](wk02_wos_journals_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-10-1.png){width=672}
:::
:::


#### Spice things up with a theme from ggthemes

Check out this [ggthemes gallery](https://yutannihilation.github.io/allYourFigureAreBelongToUs/ggthemes/)


::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
#install.packages("ggthemes")
library(ggthemes)

# count of articles by year, by journal
ggplot(both_data, aes(x = publication_year)) +
  geom_bar() +
  labs(title = "Articles per Year in TC and TCQ",
       X = "Publication Year",
       Y = "Number of Articles") +
   facet_wrap(~ source_title, ncol = 1) +
  theme_economist()
```

::: {.cell-output-display}
![](wk02_wos_journals_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-11-1.png){width=672}
:::
:::

::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
# count of articles by year, by journal
year_plot <- ggplot(both_data, aes(x = publication_year)) +
  geom_bar() +
  labs(title = "Articles per Year in TC and TCQ",
       X = "Publication Year",
       Y = "Number of Articles") +
   facet_wrap(~ source_title, ncol = 1) +
  theme_economist_white()

year_plot
```

::: {.cell-output-display}
![](wk02_wos_journals_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-12-1.png){width=672}
:::
:::


#### Add labels above the bars


::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
# add labels above the bars
year_plot <- year_plot +
  geom_text(stat = 'count', aes(label = after_stat(count)), vjust = -0.5, size = 4)

year_plot
```

::: {.cell-output-display}
![](wk02_wos_journals_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-13-1.png){width=672}
:::
:::


#### Save the chart


::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
help(ggsave)
ggsave("plots/articles_barplot.png", 
       plot = year_plot, 
       width = 8, 
       height = 6, 
       dpi = 300,
       bg = NULL)
```
:::


#### Save our dataset


::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
# save as csv

write.csv(both_data, "data_out/both_data.csv")

save(both_data, file = "data_out/both_data.RData")
```
:::


## What about other journals?

Gather and add to our visuals all articles published after 2005 from [Web of Science](https://www.webofscience.com/wos/woscc/basic-search) in these journals:

* Journal of Business and Technical Communication
* Written Communication
